I bought this game without much thought, the promise of such easy achievements as such a low price was worth the strange looks my steam friends are probably giving me through their screens.
NEKOPARA Vol. 0 is a bright, light hearted, and although dappling in your average creepy VN plots (sibling complexes etc) was quite an enjoyable experience.
It was short, taking only an hour to 100% the game including reading the entire story- but at £1.99 that's hardly something one can complain about. I reckon my boyfriend would have some concern if he saw me spending much longer ogling at animated cat girls bosoms bouncing around at the slightest movement, so the length suited it quite well.
I am aware there is a sequel/sequels, however the higher price tag for these titles (Even if they were longer in story etc) wouldn't be justifiable for me simply because of lack of depth to the story itself. I would therefore advise only buying the heavier priced sequels if they are on sale, or if you have a particular craving for catgirl ecchi.

reviewText:
Nekopara! A day in the life of a catgirl (or well, several!). Nekopara Volume 0 was developed by NEKO WORKs and published by Sekai Project on the 17th August 2015. There are currently three games to the series – Volume 0, 1 and 2.

Nekopara Volume 0 was released after Volume 1 but the game is set before the events of Volume 1. Volume 0 is set in a third person perspective, meaning you personally have very little interaction in terms of the story input. You can however pet the girls which is quite adorable.

Positives:
Music – The music to the main menu and game is really enjoyable. It’s quite upbeat and I feel it goes very well with the game.
Price – The price of this game is very low, at £1.99 it is not much money at all to invest.
Neko Paradise – If you love Cat girls, you won’t be left disappointed. They are however a bit silly but that adds to the cuteness of it all.
Optimisation – The game is heavily customisable. You can change the font of the text, speed of the text, languages, window size and the most amusing “chest bounciness”.
Save slots – There are a huge amount of save slots, I’ve found in previous VN’s the number of save slots have been pretty low, Nekopara however provides a huge amount.
Artstyle – The artstyle to the game is really good, very sharp with bright radiant colours. There are also a few slides where the game turns chibi and the result is very adorable.
Petting – this is more of a side amusement, you can pet the girls whenever you feel like.

Negatives:
Length – The length of the game is really short and will see you completing it in around 1 hour and 30 minutes (well probably quicker than that because I move really slow)
Third person perspective – There was times in which I wish I could’ve been a person in the story and be able to participate and make choices and choose favourites. Unfortunately this game takes more of a viewers point where you can’t make changes what so ever.
Censorship – The game has certain parts (Ehehehe) censored. I am against censorship because I believe it ruins artistic freedom. Although I do agree that the game should be restricted to adults only.
Loss of facial expressions – When they are angry, if you pet them suddenly they lose their angry facial expressions which can leave it looking a bit derpy.
No choices – Any choices in the game would be great but unfortunately you have none.


Volume 0 is the first ever Nekopara game I have played and it felt more like a taster because of the price and the length of the game. I did however enjoy the game because it was filled with nekos and silliness. This game may not be for everyone, especially due to it being AO and culturally different. I am looking forward to playing Volume 1 after this game because I feel the positives definitely outweigh the negatives and for the price of this game, it’s definitely worth checking out to see if you do enjoy it because if you do, you have another two nekopara games to check!

Score: Buy now

It's Nekopara, you should play it regardless of the cost, as a visual novel while it is mostly slice of life, it also has excellent writing which will keep you involved, this is a prequel and it's also 1/3rd of the cost of Volume 1 which is why it is as short as it is (I finished in 1.2 hours) and Volume 1 took me about 3 days on and off to finish, that includes reading all the nudity parts in the R18+ version.

The soundtrack in this novel includes quite a few songs from the soundtrack of Volume 1, which is comforting and also familiar, instead of trying to reinvent the wheel they simply renovated it and brought in a few changes to the OST, while also keeping true to the style.

Pros:
You can pet your cats.
You can make your cats boobs bounce.
Great writing that will keep you involved.
Familiar and comforting soundtrack.
Many of the CGs include all of the cats, and it's in true Sayori style.

Neutral:
Short length, which is really helpful for staying involved but it can also be a bit of a shame that it ends so quickly.

reviewText:
tl;dr: 6/10. It's (literally) Nekopara, but better than the first one.

Full review:
If you've come here before having read volume 1, you messed up. Read volume 1 first, or alternatively, my review of it.

Now, if you have read volume 1, you know exactly what to expect. If you just want to finish reading what you started, you probably won't be able to follow to well, but thanks nonetheless.

As far as the story goes, I found this one a tad more interesting than its predecessor, although the fact that it only covers a single day chronologically means that you're going to be reading for an hour and then idling for trading cards for the next 10 like I did. It's still the same deal, catgirls and not much happening, but we get a bit more backstory on the other catgirls and Shigure, which is welcome in my eyes. Kashou being basically a non-factor in this game was also a nice addition. I don't really like that guy.

The story is one reason I'd recommend this and volume 1, but there are two much more significant factors that influence this preference.

Firstly, Neko Works has really stepped up their game engine since the last installment. There's now a feature to pet the catgirls at any time, as long as their sprite is on the screen, and they even have three different reactions depending on where you pat them. This is a pretty neat toy which adds to the main selling point of the game - the cutesiness.

Also, the option to display dialogue from two languages, which was a little bugged in volume 1, if I recall correctly, now works more or less fine. Although it cuts off a little on some of the longer lines, it's definitely workable. This feature is great for people looking to practice Japanese, especially considering the game isn't too long and doesn't use particularly difficult language.

As for the English translation, I was (surprisingly) rather impressed. If it was done by the same guy as the first game, you did good, friend. There's still a fair bit of room for work, but considering this is a Sekai Project release, the fact that it's up to scratch is an improvement. There was one mistake in the English dialogue - writing Cinnamon instead of Coconut - which isn't really anything major, but it rustled my jimmies nonetheless. It would be nice if it got patched but I don't really care any more since I'm never going to play the game again anyway.

The other thing that led me to hitting the recommend button on this game was its price. Volume 1 was a little pricey considering how much you got out of it, but this volume, costing as much as a cup of coffee, is marketed at a much more reasonable price point, and I really don't have a reason not to recommend it.

reviewText:
Nekopara Vol. 0 is something like a standalone expansion to Vol. 1. This takes place before Vol. 1, before Kashou moved to open the bakery. There's no real central plot, it's just showcasing an average day in the Minaduki's house.

You might of noticed it's only 3 dollars. Real cheap, but that means it's very short. I read the whole thing in less than an hour, so keep that in mind.

Anything I said in my review of Vol. 1 basically applies here. It's cute, silly, lighthearted fun with all the characters performing their daily activites they would normally do; make food, going out, etc etc. Chocola and Vanilla aren't really the main stars anymore as all 6 of the catgirls share the spotlight now, making sure they all have their moments within the story, along with Shigure from time to time. Kashou isn't even in the story, so he's not focused on at all. While it may seemed pretty cramped to try to focus on 6 characters, you really do get to see the personalities of all the catgirls shine in one way or another, and you really get a feel for them more, certainly more than you saw in Vol. 1 (Besides Chocola and Vanilla, they kind of took a backseat) Basically, it's still got the nice writing and tone that the last one had, if you liked Vol. 1, you'll feel right at home here.

There's no real difference in the animation or music department, it's all the same from Vol. 1, but luckily it's still fully animated and voice acted in Japanese just like the last one.

There's a petting mode. You can pet anyone you like at (almost) anytime. So that's good.


So overall, Vol. 0 is a really short but sweet experience that gives you more to read if you wanted to have more Nekopara. If you haven't played Vol. 1 yet, go pick this up first since it's cheaper and you can get an idea of all the characters and how they are.

7/10

reviewText:
Nekopara Vol. 0. This story takes place when Main guy still lived at home and therefore coexisted with his harem of cat girls. Main Male doesn’t even really exist Vol 0 . He appears at one point and is often the topic of discussion, but never exerts himself as a protagonist. Well, the cats and younger sister. She might as well be part of the harem though as her brother complex is played up once again for amusement and for some creepy as hell.

If all you’re looking to do for 45 minutes is watch cutesy cat girls to goof off, then you’re in for a great time. However, if you’re looking to learn much of anything more about the cast or Main past you’ll be sorely disappointed. Then again, it’s worth recalling that the original visual novel was fairly simple too. It’s just unfortunate to see how vapid this release turned out. As with before, this is still a visual novel that offers the player no choices at any point. There is one ending and everyone receives it if they read through to completion. You’ll find achievements to collect, though they are related mostly to petting each character. The “pet” mechanic is kinder cute and doesn’t actually impact the progression.

I would recommeded play vol 1 if you enjoyed so much or just want learn more about Cat girls, mystery main guy back story ect....

reviewText:
Ahhhh. NEKO WORKs return with another installment of their Nekopara (Cat Paradise) series. First and foremost, I’d like to say that this game is a filler game for fans of the first game to satisfy the players until Nekopara Vol. 2 comes out in December 2015! Also, this review might be shorter than my usual reviews because I’m going to touch up on A LOT on my Nekopara Vol. 1 review. Now I’m going to start off with the first thing most people see and look at when there’s a new game out on Steam, it’s the price. This VN is worth much more than it’s currently priced at on Steam. At $2.99, you get a few hours worth of the moe goodness that is Nekopara. With some new added features, this game is definitely a must-buy for Nekopara and Visual Novel fans.

Starting off, there is 1 major new feature implemented in this volume of the Nekopara series and that is the ability to pet them. You can pet them in 3 locations to get different reactions and expressions using their “e-mote” system which I talked about on my previous review. Those reactions and expressions are for me to know and for you to find out. With this volume being a prequel to the original first game, you get some backstory on the location of your character (Kashou) of where he lived as well as how he lived at his old family house. With Nekopara Vol.1 you only got to know 2 of all the catgirls which were Chocola and Vanilla, in this VN though, you get to know the other catgirls from the way they talk to the their personalities. Each catgirl is unique in their own way with their own struggles, insecurities and pleasures in life.

I only got about 1.5 hours of game time from what Steam tells me. I finished the game from beginning to end with a plethora of emotions ranging from happiness to frustration to sadness throughout my entire playthrough. The main storyline of this prequel is that Kashou (you) are gone for the day and you see what the catgirls and your sister do when you’re away. Featuring 15 scenes or “episodes” going from your sister and the 6 catgirls waking you up, prepare breakfast, clean the house, go on a walk, make dinner, take a bath and eventually sleep together. Lastly, I want to add that this game is for all ages and there is no “hidden” content like the previous game except the bath scene which covers the important bits with the magical mist that appears in most ecchi anime.That’s pretty much all there is to this. Again, for $2.99; you are getting your entire money’s worth AND MORE! If you haven’t already bought this, go right now, stop reading and enjoy the cute nekos that you can pet!

TL;DR: Cute nekos return and this time you can pet them! All for $2.99!

reviewText:
I highly recommend this Visual Novel!

PROS:
- Every single character is unique, fun, interesting and charismatic.
- Very fun soundtrack
- The nice voice acting, visuals, music, sound effects really set up the mood and atmosphere for experience.
- Low price for an hour long Visual Novel (which in my opinion, is fully worth it)
- You get to experience the prequel to Nekopara Volume 1
- The story is pleasant to follow and flows naturally
- It's a simple, yet absolutely entertaining story to follow
- It appeals to various types of comedy
- The art is absolutely beautiful
- It contains a feature to increase or decrease breasts physics to your liking.
- A diverse cast of characters so you can really dive in their personalities and pick a favorite

CONS:
- A few (and I do mean few) typos and mistranslations ( me, where the word should've been my and toilet spelled as toliet)

Bottom line, you get your money's worth. I'm satisfied and it was an amusing experience. I felt like I was fully into that universe and that I was WITH the characters experiencing their day with them. If you're looking for a low price, yet high quality visual novel, this is for you!

With that said, I'm on my way to put Nekopara Volume 1 on my wishlist!

reviewText:
I highly recommend this Visual Novel!

PROS:
- Every single character is unique, fun, interesting and charismatic.
- Very fun soundtrack
- The nice voice acting, visuals, music, sound effects really set up the mood and atmosphere for experience.
- Low price for an hour long Visual Novel (which in my opinion, is fully worth it)
- You get to experience the prequel to Nekopara Volume 1
- The story is pleasant to follow and flows naturally
- It's a simple, yet absolutely entertaining story to follow
- It appeals to various types of comedy
- The art is absolutely beautiful
- It contains a feature to increase or decrease breasts physics to your liking.
- A diverse cast of characters so you can really dive in their personalities and pick a favorite

CONS:
- A few (and I do mean few) typos and mistranslations ( me, where the word should've been my and toilet spelled as toliet)

Bottom line, you get your money's worth. I'm satisfied and it was an amusing experience. I felt like I was fully into that universe and that I was WITH the characters experiencing their day with them. If you're looking for a low price, yet high quality visual novel, this is for you!

With that said, I'm on my way to put Nekopara Volume 1 on my wishlist!

While the original mainly was just about Chocola and Vanilla, all six of them have equal screen time this go around. It was fun to revisit the familiar characters and their personalities while getting to know the other four catgirls more since they had more minor roles last time. reviewText: What Nekopara Vol. 0 teaches us is that beneath the cheerful facade lurks chaos and mayhem. The story takes place across a single day, and every situation, no matter how simple it appears at first, spirals out of control. Every character in the household is a ticking bomb, who desperately needs the help of everyone else to not self destruct. A few times they’re brought to the brink of dissolution, only to be pulled back in the last second by one of them.\n\nIn Vol. 1 we saw the brother try to escape the household, only to have everyone follow him to his bakery. In Vol 0 we learn why. The second he left, their reality must have degenerated into unlivable conditions. They might have tried to respect his decision to live alone, but that simply didn’t work. Self preservation instincts kicked in, and they followed him. This is an essential addition for understanding the gritty reality of living with cat girls. It includes a petting mode for total immersion.

Sigh... this was gifted to me by one of two possible friends just to torment me. It's hard to decline a gift from a friend who has financial troubles and not let her feel like she wasted her money for nothing... despite I gave warnings ahead of time I would decline it... the guilt was too much to possibly bare.

1st ReadThis was hell... utter hell. Usually don't find VN's that all interesting, mainly Anime ones (looking at you Sakura series), as I'm not much of a reader but a doer, if that makes any sense to you. That being said: To me usually VN's =/= Game as there's little to no interactive to be done by the reader, even if it's choice, but to read a story. To The Moon is a fine line between the two and I enjoyed it very much.

Here's what I gathered from this game... btw I read this before Vol 1, which was also gifted by same friend.

Characters: Unique in their own way, yet they all have their moments of putting the dunce cap on, like the air freshener scene. Shigure however creeps me the hell out... someone is overly obsessive for their sibling.
Writing: I noticed a few Spelling mistakes along with grammar in terms of missing words... but seemed alright.
Music: Most of it just didn't seem fitting or out of place... one track sounds like a gameshow for pete sake!
[s]Voice: HAD IT TURNED OFF THE WHOLE TIME, LOOK FOR ANOTHER REVIEW ABOUT THIS![/s]
Story: Will admit it was funny in it's weird uguu" way... but a lot of it was cliche anime tropes...
Animation: Half the time it looks like their doing a shuffle. The 2D art looking 3D made me have very little motion sickness
date: which adds up more as I read to the point I had to stop and call it a day before continuing...\n\nGuess I can't deny it's alright... overall didn't enjoy it
recommended: but again I'm not a VN person and I'm picky when it comes to Anime media. If you're an Anime fanatic like most people on steam I keep running into
